g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
As noted above, shifting development pathways and accelerating mitigation involve a broad range of
makers, at multiple geographical and temporal scales. They require a credible
conciling perspectives and balancing potential side
and losers and implementing compensatory measures to ensure an inclusive just transition
Gambhir et al. 2018; Diffenbaugh and Burke 2019)
processes are designed to manage the risk of inequitable or non
can be subject to regulatory capture by special interests, or outright opposition from a variety o
stakeholders. Information asymmetry between government and business may shape the results of
consultative processes. Long experience of political management of change demonstrates that managing
such risks is not easy, and requires sufficiently strong and
next section on Just Transition (4.5) addr
Equity is an ethical and at times economic imperative, but it is also instrumentally an enabler of deeper
. The literature supports a range of
bon transformation, and it identifies a
number of difficulties in drawing definitive quantitative conclusions (e.g., comparisons of costs &
benefits among different actors, the existence of non
tude, 3.6). One of the most important of these dimensions is the distributional
consequences of mitigation, as well as a range of equity considerations arising from the uncertainty in
net benefits, as well as from the distribution of costs and benefits amo
2019; Caney 2016; Lahn and Bradley 2016; Lenferna 2018a; Kartha et al. 2018b; Robiou Du Pont et
even just seeking corrective justice including for historical
. For an assessment of literature on fairness in NDCs, see 4.2.2.7.
Equity issues are often discussed in the literature via frameworks that are well
literature and that have a strong bearing on effort
sharing, but have not yet been quantitatively modelled
and expressed in the form of an emissions allocation
While there is extensive literature on equity fram
Benedict et al. 2018; Pye et al. 2020; Robiou du Pont and
on et al. 2020; Holz et al. 2018; Pozo et al. 2020)
focus on allocation of a global carbon budget among countries based on quantified equity frameworks.
The implicit normative choices made in these analysis have limitations
there are many ethical parameters that could be introduced to enrich the existing quantitative
Introducing these ethical frames into conventional quantification approaches generally implies greater
emitting populations, suggesting that the approaches that are typically
